body: To the Editor: It is indeed ''a matter of scale'' here in Brooklyn. Bruce Ratner is gambling that there is a bottomless market for 3,000 market-rate condos in the Atlantic Yards. But have the developer's plans taken into account the 1,210 condos proposed for Brooklyn Bridge Park; the 1,000 condos proposed for Downtown Brooklyn; and the many smaller
title: Brooklyn's Railyards: The Fight Continues

body: To the Editor: Re ''The Pride of Columbus'' (Dec. 11): While I was saddened to read of Catherine Woods's death, to crown this young woman ''the pride of Columbus'' is to imply that Ohio's capital city is a tiny hamlet devoid of a world-class science and technology enterprise (Battelle); a symphony orchestra; a nationally recognized postsecondary
title: A View of Ohio By Way of New York

body: THE question sounded laughable: Given that the national median home price recently calculated by the National Association of Realtors is $220,000, is it possible to buy something for that price in New York City? Or even, just to provide some wiggle room, up to $250,000? The initial reactions of real estate brokers in all five boroughs included:
title: What You Can Get for $220,000

body: EARLY in ''The Squid and the Whale,'' Noah Baumbach's semiautobiographical film about divorce among the literati, the teenage Walt Berkman is seen sitting alone in a high-school classroom when a potential girlfriend strikes up a conversation: ''You live in Park Slope, right?'' The answer is complicated -- his parents live apart and have joint
title: URBAN TACTICS; A Movie, a Mirror

body: FOR Michael and Elizabeth Turbé, newly married and looking for a starter house, Peekskill was just the right fit. ''It's suburban here, but not too suburban, and it's a city, but not too big of one,'' Mr. Turbé said. ''Even more important,'' he said, ''for people like us just starting out, we were also able to find the kind of place we always
title: LIVING IN/Peekskill, N.Y.; Matching a Dream to a Budget

body: Teachers in New York City expressed a kind of wary relief yesterday afternoon that after more than two years without a new contract, their union had negotiated a deal with the Bloomberg administration. Many also said they were glad that the union, the United Federation of Teachers, would now withdraw its threat to strike. But some teachers were
title: Teachers Embrace Settlement, If Not Raise

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CITY MYSTERIES; Square Triangles And Tucked-Away Squirrels

body: The shoppers and young families strolling along Seventh Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, can normally slurp their iced coffees, nosh on bagels and French pastries and browse for books far from the tumultuous politics of City Hall. But now it seems they cannot escape the mayoral candidates and their campaign workers prospecting for votes, as
title: Mayoral Rivals Fight for Turf in Brownstone Brooklyn

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WINDSOR TERRACE; A Gas Station Seeks Growth, The Neighbors See Trouble

body: IS Brooklyn the new Paris? When BabyCenter.com, a San Francisco Web site, surveyed 310,000 parents and ranked the most popular baby names for 2004, it found that a surprising entry was moving up the national charts. Brooklyn, along with variant spellings like Brooklynn and Brooke Lynn, reached No. 84 on the site's list of girls' names. That's
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/THE FUTURE; Brooklyn Babes

body: Williamsburg Village Style Freddy Jakubowski has tended bar at the Greenpoint Tavern on Bedford Avenue since 1985. It was 1992 when a place arrived unlike any other there, a little restaurant called the L Cafe. "Some girl opened it," Mr. Jakubowski said. "She was a good girl. I'm not much of an architect or a decorator, but she did it something
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/TIPPING POINTS; The Day When Back in the Day Ended

body: The Kensington Stables shelter a quiet, rustic Brooklyn intersection from the rumbling traffic a block away on the Ocean Parkway, from the stampede of development beyond it, and in some ways, from time itself. Early yesterday afternoon, children rode ponies down Caton Place, and a 12-year-old Andalusian quarterhorse cross named Emma dozed in an
title: Sale of a Stable Threatens What Passes for a Pasture in Brooklyn

author: Jessica Grose is an M.F.A. candidate at Columbia and the editorial assistant at Spin.com. She lives in Brooklyn.
body: SINCE I know what it's like to sob on nearly every single form of public transportation in the New York metropolitan area, I can tell you with authority that crying on the subway is the most cathartic. I suppose I'm not a full-fledged expert in local mass transit emoting; I have yet to cry on the Staten Island Ferry or the tram to Roosevelt Island.
title: MODERN LOVE; Me? I'm Just Fine (Whimper). Really (Sob).

body: To the Editor: ''Salvation in the Classroom,'' by Peter Quinn (Op-Ed, March 13), gave an assessment of the values that Catholic school passed on to generations of children of immigrants: a solid basic education. As a veteran of 12 years of Catholic schooling, I agree with this assessment. However, corporal punishment deeply tainted my experience
title: A Catholic Education

body: A day after spring seemed to burst out of hiding, winter came charging back to the New York region yesterday with a storm that brought plunging temperatures and wind-whipped snow that appeared strangely immune to gravity -- blowing up and sideways as well as down. From street corners, office windows and front porches, many watched in dismay as the
title: In Wind, Snow, Cold and Frustration, a Dangerous Storm
